title: Erdős Problem #1020: The Erdős Matching Conjecture
description: Let f(n;r,k) be max edges in r-uniform hypergraph with no k independent edges. Conjecture: f(n;r,k) = max(C(rk-1,r), C(n,r)-C(n-k+1,r)). Solved for r=2,3. Upper bound: (k-1)C(n-1,r-1). OPEN for r≥4.

overview.historicalContext: The Erdős Matching Conjecture is one of the central problems in extremal hypergraph theory. For graphs (r=2), Erdős-Gallai (1959) solved it completely. For 3-uniform hypergraphs, Łuczak-Mieczkowska (2014) confirmed the conjecture after decades of partial progress. For r≥4, despite major advances by Frankl, Huang-Loh-Sudakov, and others, the general conjecture remains open. Two natural constructions achieve the conjectured bound.
overview.problemStatement: Let f(n; r, k) be the maximum number of edges in an r-uniform hypergraph on n vertices containing no k pairwise disjoint edges. Conjecture: f(n; r, k) = max(C(rk-1, r), C(n, r) - C(n-k+1, r)) for all r ≥ 3.
overview.proofStrategy: The Lean formalization defines r-uniform hypergraphs with a matching predicate. The function f(n;r,k) is the supremum over hypergraphs avoiding k-matchings. Two constructions provide the conjectured lower bound. Frankl's upper bound (k-1)C(n-1,r-1) is stated as an axiom. Solved cases (r=2,3) and partial results (small n, large n regimes) are captured.
keyInsights: Construction 1: All r-edges on rk-1 vertices (can't fit k disjoint edges)
Construction 2: All edges meeting a fixed (k-1)-set (any k share a vertex)
Large n: Huang-Loh-Sudakov proved for n ≥ 3kr²

conclusion.summary: The Erdős Matching Conjecture predicts the exact maximum edges in an r-uniform hypergraph avoiding k disjoint edges. The formula max(C(rk-1,r), C(n,r)-C(n-k+1,r)) is proven for r=2,3 and verified in various regimes for larger r. Frankl's upper bound (k-1)C(n-1,r-1) is always true. The conjecture remains open for r ≥ 4 despite substantial partial progress.
conclusion.implications: This connects to Turán-type extremal problems, the Erdős-Ko-Rado theorem, and hypergraph matching theory. A proof would unify our understanding of when hypergraphs must contain large matchings. The conjecture has applications to coding theory and combinatorial design.
openQuestions: Is the conjecture true for r = 4?
Can the gap between small n and large n regimes be closed?
Is there a unified proof approach for all r?
What is the structure of extremal hypergraphs?
